Matt Shepard, the gay college student savagely beaten last week in Wyoming,

have been shot, and killed.
have been shot, and killed.

before we ask ourselves whether or not God actually wants them around.
&gt;&gt;I'm gay.
&gt;&gt;Dad, I'm gay.
&gt;&gt;I'm gay.
&gt;&gt;Will Phillips is refusing to pledge allegiance to the flag
in his 5th grade classroom until there really is liberty and justice for all.
&gt;&gt;There is a push underway to lift the ban
that prohibits gay men from donating blood.
&gt;&gt;Gay men have not been allowed to donate blood since 1985,
because of a fear of HIV.
It's a policy that some say is way outdated, and unneccessary.
&gt;&gt;Homosexual behavior is harmful, not only to society,
but more importantly to the individuals who engage in that behavior.

&gt;&gt;Homosexuals, and atheists, are not to be allowed to be registered 
 as leaders, or members, of the Boy Scouts of America.
&gt;&gt;How can we, as people who make the laws,
say to one small group of our fellow citizens,
"You know, there's something about you that some people don't like,

so you are not eligible for work, you can 
 be fired, you can't get a promotion."
&gt;&gt;I hardly think that bullying is a real issue in schools.

&gt;&gt;I want you to meet a little boy named Asher Brown. 
  He lived in Texas, he was 13 years old.

I say "was", in the past, because he 
 shot himself in the head last Thursday.
&gt;&gt;Billy Lucas of Greensburg, Indiana, was just fifteen years old

when bullying pushed him over the edge.
&gt;&gt;Hi, this is Jamey from Buffalo, New York.

I just wanted to tell you that it does get

&gt;&gt;Fourteen year old Jamey Rodemeyer took his life Sunday.
&gt;&gt;Let's do this one for Jamey.
&gt;&gt;When government starts to tell us who can love, and what is good love,
I do have a problem with that, I do.
&gt;&gt;Today I'm announcing my support for a low that gives our same-sex couples
in our state a right to receive a marriage license in Washington,
the same right given to our heterosexual couples.

&gt;&gt;I believe that a marriage should be between a man and 
 a woman, no offense to anybody out there,

[audience begins to applaud and cheer loudly]
but that's how I was raised, and that's 
 how I think it should be, between a man and a woman.

[audience begins to applaud and cheer loudly]
but that's how I was raised, and that's 
 how I think it should be, between a man and a woman.

&gt;&gt;It was the most controversial state issue on the ballot, 
 you know I'm talking about Proposition 8,

There are still a few votes to be counted, 
 but it looks like the measure has passed.
&gt;&gt;If you're for equal rights, why would you get married right now?
It's like joining a country club that doesn't allow blacks or jews.
There's no difference!
&gt;&gt;An open statement by a service-member that he or she is a homosexual

will create a rebuttable presumption that he or 
 she intends to engage in prohibited conduct.
&gt;&gt;I am an infantry platoon leader in the New York Army National Guard,
and by saying three words to you today, "I am gay,"
those three words are in violation of Title 10 of the US code.
&gt;&gt;Lieutenant Dan Choi has been fired from the U.S. Military.

&gt;&gt;Florida governor Charlie Crist has ordered the state to stop enforcing

&gt;&gt;California's ban on same-sex marriage was overturned by a federal judge in San Francisco.

&gt;&gt;On February 12 an openly gay 15-year-old boy named Larry, 
 who was an 8th grader in Oxnard, California,
was murdered by a fellow 8th-grader named Brandon.
Larry was killed because he was gay.
&gt;&gt;One of the most obnoxious and offensive vestiges of
our criminal justice system from another era is the gay panic defense,

the idea that if a gay person makes a pass at you 
 and you don't like it, you can fly into a rage
shoot and kill that person, and that's some kind of a defense.
&gt;&gt;We are not a nation that says "Don't ask, don't tell."
We are a nation that says, "Out of many, we are one."
&gt;&gt;[crowd, shouting together] Three!  Two!  One!  [Loud whooping and cheering.]

&gt;&gt;We begin tonight with something brand new in 
 America today.  It is day one.
&gt;&gt;The long controversial Don't-Ask-Don't-Tell policy expired at midnight.
&gt;&gt;Some say domestic partnerships are the same as marriage.

&gt;&gt;You can love that person, but you can't marry them.  That's wrong.
&gt;&gt;It's separate-but-equal, I can be a second-class citizen.
&gt;&gt;I cannot legally come up with an argument against same-sex marriage.
&gt;&gt;To all of the gay and lesbian kids out there tonight

who have been told that they are less-than by their 
 churches, by the government, or by their families:
You are beautiful, wonderful creatures of value.

&gt;&gt;Our mission is to reach out and teach 
 people to love, and not to hate.
&gt;&gt;When the message out there is so horrible,

that to be gay, you can get killed for 
 it, we need to change the message.

&gt;&gt;Things will get easier.
&gt;&gt;It gets better.

&gt;&gt;The sexual orientation of my parents has had zero 
 effect on the content of my character.
&gt;&gt;[overlapping the previous speaker]...content of their character. I have a dream...
&gt;&gt;We too have a dream!
&gt;&gt;Are you listening?!!

&gt;&gt;This is done.
&gt;&gt;Bless God, and bless the gays.
&gt;&gt;Ayes: 33, Nays: 29  [WILD cheering, roaring cheers]
&gt;&gt;Two down, two to go.

[tiny burst of voice, unintelligible to captioner, followed by a short 
 phrase by a different speaker, also unintelligible to captioner.]
&gt;&gt;Love, love, love.
&gt;&gt;And you, and you, and you... gotta give 'em hope.
&gt;&gt;Every American citizen has the right.
&gt;&gt;Be on the right side of history.
&gt;&gt;Thank you very much.
&gt;&gt;Larry was not a second-class citizen.  I am not a second-class citizen.
It is okay if you're gay.

comments.text:
Excerpts from a Recent New England Journal of Medicine Editorial In Support 
of Same-Sex Marriage: 

"A fundamental tenet of all medical care is the acceptance of patients as 
they are, for who they are, with respect and without prejudice or personal 
agendas. 

.....Same-sex marriage should be accepted both as a matter of justice and 
as a measure that promotes health. Marriage as an institution is about 
stable, long-term relationships, which we know encourage health, reduce the 
risk of some diseases, and promote healthy families. All health 
professionals know that in those with chronic and severe illness, care 
almost always relies in part on family. And when things get really 
difficult, as when life and death decisions need to be made, physicians 
know that talking with a patient's partner is not legally the same as 
working with a patient's spouse. Many same-sex couples are now raising 
children, and the health of those children demands that their parents have 
the full rights and protection of marriage. In our society, marriage is 
often essential to obtaining and keeping adequate health insurance coverage 
for both members of a couple and for their children. 

.....The Supreme Court should require the full recognition of same-sex 
marriage throughout this country. If the Court rules otherwise, whatever 
the legal logic, a clear injustice will result. And that injustice would 
damage the health and welfare of millions of Americans."﻿

BREAKING NEWS - In a pending case regarding Puerto Rico's ban on civil 
marriage for same sex couples, the government of Puerto Rico has just 
submitted a new brief to the court acknowledging that the ban is 
unconstitutional, and is abandoning their defense of the ban. This will 
result in Puerto Rico providing civil marriage for same sex couples very 
soon, no later than the ruling from the U.S. Supreme Court in June. From 
the Puerto Rico government's new brief :

 "Because Puerto Rico’s marriage ban impermissibly burdens Plaintiffs´ 
rights to the equal protection of the laws and the fundamental right to 
marry, we have decided to cease defending its constitutionality based on an 
independent assessment about its validity under the current state of the 
law."﻿

comments.text:
It often refers more to a strong discomfort or fear of one's own feelings 
of homosexual arousal, or even just the fear or worry that at some point 
they MIGHT have such feelings, even if they typically don't have such 
feelings. It is a result of someone having developed a strong aversion to 
the idea of homosexuality, which goes beyond something like a mere 
religious-based opinion of 'disapproval'.

And this can happen regardless whether the person is straight or gay. 
Whereas someone who doesn't have any particular negative view about 
homosexuality and has not developed this aversion would not have that 
discomfort, fear, or worry about the topic because they would not be 
internalizing it. 

The term sometimes gets misused and tossed around loosely and sometimes 
gets used in cases where it would be more accurate to say that someone is 
prejudiced, or perhaps bigoted. What were you doing or saying that caused 
someone to call you that?

comments.text:
+Azad Ward 1. No, you don't need to wait until same sex marriage is 
'everywhere' to see the facts. In places that have had same sex marriage 
for ten or fifteen years, there is ten or fifteen years of data. And the 
data shows that allowing gay couples to get a legal marriage instead of 
living without those protections has had no effect on the procreative 
activities of ANY citizens, gay or straight, and has had no effect at 
all other than to provide these couples with EQUAL LEGAL TREATMENT.

2. And things that are not a disease obviously cannot have a cure, so the 
reason nobody is finding a 'cure' is because homosexuality is just a 
naturally occurring and normal variation of human sexual expression. And 
it's interesting to note that you are now referring to homosexuality as a 
"disease". Where is your evidence of that? Why don't any health 
organizations agree with you?

3. You are now suggesting that some gay people have bribed hundreds of 
thousands of health care workers and researchers to falsify research data 
for many decades, from the lab assistants to the top of the World Health 
Organization. That is not a serious argument and it makes you sound like a 
crazy conspiracy theorist. It's baseless nonsense.

4. Of course some gay people have married the opposite sex. But there's no 
evidence that these gays did so because the government was encouraging them 
to do so by denying them a legal marriage license document with a same sex 
partner, and THAT is the point. And even that website makes it clear that a 
gay person marrying the opposite sex is a bad thing, and that straight 
people should marry straight people and gay people should marry gay people. 
Otherwise you have people being miserable in dishonest marriages, and 
there's obviously no states interest in making that happen. It serves no 
beneficial purpose and it DENIES EQUAL TREATMENT WHICH VIOLATES THE 
CONSTITUTION.

5. There is absolutely no evidence anywhere to support your claim that 
giving gays a civil marriage license causes fewer births 'because it makes 
gays adopt instead of marrying and procreating with the opposite sex'. 
That's not the reason the laws are changing. They are changing because same 
sex couples who were being HARMED by laws that denied them marriage went to 
court and had the law challenged and the court ruled that they were right, 
the law was unjust, harmful, unnecessary and unconstitutional. THAT is why 
gays are marrying. Because the law that prevented it was unconstitutional. 
That is a FACT.

6. No, just as I said above, the bans on same sex marriage are all being 
repealed because they violated the Constitution. The government had no 
authority to make such laws because they were a needless restriction on a 
targeted group and denied them equal protection for no valid reason. It has 
nothing to do with the government wanting to either encourage gays to marry 
the opposite sex because of your idea that 'it's wrong to not want to do 
so', or to marry the same sex to 'encourage a reduction in birth rates'. It 
is because the law violated the Constitution.

And yes, anyone is legally allowed to procreate regardless if they are gay 
or straight or married or not. It is best to raise kids in a stable married 
home, regardless if both parents are biological, or if one is, or if 
neither are. So it's best to allow all couples who are raising kids to 
marry. There are MANY cases where a woman marries a man and has children, 
they divorce, and then she gets honest with herself that she is really 
attracted to women. So she meets her new partner, another woman, and they 
raise her kids together as a couple, with one biological parent and one 
step parent. Like lots of opposite sex couples with one biological parent 
and one step parent. And  denying them the protections of legal marriage 
would needlessly harm their family. And that's why those bans are being 
overturned.

7. Yes, there CAN be cases where the law is allowed to treat some people 
differently, when there is a valid reason, but NOT when there is no valid 
reason. For example, you can make a law denying a drivers license to blind 
people. Yes, this treats them differently than other citizens, but it is 
necessary to 'advance the states interest' in public safety. You CANNOT 
make a law denying a drivers license to people with red hair, or people who 
are left-handed, because there is no rational justification for treating 
people differently on that basis. Just like there is no rational reason to 
deny the protections of marriage to couples based on the fact that they are 
the same sex. Doing so is not rationally related to a legitimate goal for a 
law. It merely imposes harmful discrimination for its own sake and has no 
legitimate useful purpose. THAT is why the courts are overturning those 
bans. Got that?

8. So now you still won't accept the results of peer-reviewed scientific 
studies unless you can personally contact every participant in these 
studies and re-create the entire study yourself?  Do you understand what 
'peer-reviewed' means? These studies have already been subjected to 
rigorous challenge by other researchers. But whatever, you are free to 
personally insist on clinging to some made-up personal 'theory' that 
homosexuality is a 'mental disorder' or a 'disease', even though decades of 
research by every major health care agency proves this wrong, and even 
though you are basing this idea on rationale that has nothing to do with 
how something like that is actually determined, and instead basing it on 
nothing more than the baseless assumption that someone has a 'mental 
disorder' or a 'disease' simply because they have no interest in having sex 
with and procreating with the opposite sex. If that kind of delusional 
thinking makes you happy, knock yourself out. 

When you say it's "unbelievable", you are basing that on the assumption 
that everyone "should" be straight and everyone "should" want to procreate 
with the opposite sex. That is just your bias and there is no reason to 
automatically believe that everyone "should" do so. The fact is that some 
people are just gay. They always have been. And there is no reason to 
assume that they "should" be straight. Are you aware that in the past, 
people thought that everyone "should" be right-handed and they went to 
great effort to force ALL children to be right handed? This was a biased 
assumption about what everyone "should" be based on some religious dogma. 
Some people are gay, and there's no reason to assume that they "should not" 
be gay.

8. You end with more delusional conspiracy theory nonsense with zero 
evidence


Look, we can go on with this forever, and there is no law that says you 
have to change your views, but the bottom line is that laws which denied 
the protections of marriage to gay couples were unjust, needlessly harmful, 
and violated the Constitution's requirement for providing our citizens with 
the equal protection of our laws. That is a proven fact, fully documented 
in over forty recent state and federal court cases all across this country. 
You don't have to like it, you don't have to understand it, you can ignore 
this truth if you want. But the fact remains that these laws could not be 
allowed to continue harming gay citizens by depriving them of their rights, 
and THAT is why they were overturned. Not because of anything to do with 
birth rates. They were overturned because we do not allow pointlessly 
harmful and unconstitutional laws to remain in effect. They get taken to 
court, proved unconstitutional, and they get overturned, and we continue to 
move toward our constitutional ideals of liberty and justice for all 
citizens.

comments.text:
+Azad Ward 
1. No, it DOES matter that gay couples have been marrying for many years 
because it means all of your idiotic 'the sky will fall if the gays start 
marrying' arguments are already proven false by years of facts.

2. So now you're saying that this magic "medication" doesn't exist? You're 
admitting your earlier comment was bullshit? Okay.

3. You then claim once again that "the gays are preventing people from 
studying this!" as an excuse for why this magic medication hasn't been 
found yet. How convenient for you. Except it's bullshit because any health 
agency or medical research agency or drug company can study whatever they 
want to study, and your claim that "gays are stopping them!" is more random 
bullshit that you just dreamed up to prop up your other dumb claims. The 
truth is that there is no reason for any of these entities to try to come 
up with any 'cure' for something that is not a 'disorder' and has no need 
of a 'cure'. They understand this. You don't. That's your problem, not 
theirs.

4. You then claim that gays choose to marry the opposite sex BECAUSE they 
are denied a marriage license with a gay partner, but again you have zero 
evidence of this. And it wouldn't be a valid goal for the state anyway.

5. Then, you claim they have kids with that opposite sex spouse but they 
would never choose to be a biological parent if they married a same sex 
spouse, and again the facts of the last decade prove you wrong. Gay people 
can and do choose to be a biological parent if they want to. They always 
have, regardless if the state offers them a legal marriage or not. They 
sometimes raise their own biological child with a same sex partner they 
meet after the child was born, who becomes a step parent, just like lots of 
opposite sex couples raising kids where one is the biological parent and 
the other is a step parent. They may choose to use assisted reproduction 
techniques, just like lots and lots of opposite sex couples where one 
wishes to be a biological parent and they cannot procreate with their 
spouse. And adoption is a GOOD thing and serves a valuable purpose. It 
rescues children who were abandoned by their straight parents who 
procreated irresponsibly and walked away from their responsibilities. 
leaving their kids to be cared for by the state and other citizens.

And there is no reason for the law to disadvantage ANY of these couples by 
targeting them to deny them equal protections, whether they are both the 
biological parents, whether one of them is the biological parent and the 
other is the step parent, whether they use assisted reproduction or not, 
whether they adopt or not, whether they raise any kids at all, and whether 
they are the same or the opposite sex. You keep trying to apply rules to 
same sex couples for things that ALSO apply to opposite sex couples, which 
makes your arguments illogical and invalid. You would know all of this if 
you would stop being so ignorant and read the trial rulings and get the 
facts.

6. You NOW claim that you never said the government should try to coerce 
gays into marrying someone of the opposite sex and procreating with them, 
but that's clearly a lie. You have repeatedly tried to argue that this is 
exactly what you think the government should do, and that you think the way 
to do that is for the state to harm gays by denying them the right to marry 
the person they want to marry, and thus forcing them to marry the opposite 
sex if they wish to avoid the terrible harm caused when a couple is denied 
the legal protections of marriage. And you offer some argument about 'fewer 
births' as justification for all of this. Of course none of that is valid 
because the state has no such interest in persuading gays to do that, and 
even if it tried to, that's not a valid goal for the state and not a valid 
purpose for a law, and it has nothing to do with birth rates anyway, as has 
been abundantly proven in case after case. Anyone, gay or straight, who 
wishes to procreate, can do so, regardless if they are legally married to 
anyone. But that is what you have repeatedly tried to argue. Because you 
STILL won't look at the facts.

7. You say 'law comes later'. No, since the entire topic of this video and 
this debate is the question of RIGHTS for gay citizens and how they ought 
to be treated by our laws, and whether our laws can deny them important 
rights like their right to EQUAL PROTECTION, this entire topic is clearly a 
matter of LAW. What the law can do, what it cannot do, what makes the law 
constitutional or unconstitutional. For this issue, the question of LAW 
comes first and last. As I have explained to you, your opinion about gays 
and my opinion about gays and the general public's opinion about gays is 
irrelevant to this question. You are completely ignoring the reality of how 
this issue is decided. It is decided by applying the process of 
constitutional law to examine the law. It is not decided by anyone's 
personal opinion about the group being affected.

8. There are decades of research using a wide variety of standardized 
methods for determining if someone has a 'mental disorder' and these have 
been used for studying the question of whether homosexuality has anything 
to do with the criteria that would classify someone as having a 'mental 
disorder'. These don't include "surveys", as you keep suggesting. They are 
tests which reveal if there is a negative impact on a person's ability to 
perceive reality accurately, or on their ability to participate in and 
contribute to society as others do, or on their ability to respond to 
situations and stimuli as others do, and they are studies of huge amounts 
of statistical data.

One of the early studies was done by Dr. Evelyn Hooker, who took a group of 
straight people and a group of gay people and had them all tested by other 
doctors, who were not made aware of the sexual orientation of the subjects, 
using a variety of these standard tests. The doctors were then asked to 
review the test results and try to determine which subjects were straight 
and which were gay. They concluded that there was no way to tell, and there 
was no indication in the test results which would suggest any pattern of 
'mental health' being linked to sexual orientation.

Other research has been done by reviewing huge amounts of statistical data 
about large numbers of people, including school records, military 
performance records, employment records (to determine things like a 
subjects ability to keep a job) legal records to look for patterns 
regarding getting into trouble with the law, etc. These reveal that being 
gay has no negative effect on any of these standard indicators of a 
person's ability to participate in and contribute to society.

You can also look up the works of Dr. J.S. Bohan. You can also find out 
what these groups have to say about their research: American Psychiatric 
Association, the American Psychology Association, the American Medical 
Association, the North American Counsel on Adoptable Children, American 
Academy of Family Physicians, American Academy of Pediatrics, National 
Association of Social Workers, the World Health Organization, etc.

And in NONE of these studies has any group suggested that there is any 
validity to your idiotic idea of classifying someone as having a 'mental 
disorder' simply because they have no interest in having sex with and 
procreating with someone of the opposite sex. They say things like this, 
from the APA:

"Lesbian, gay and bisexual orientations are not disorders. Research has 
found no inherent association between any of these sexual orientations and 
psychopathology. Both heterosexual behavior and homosexual behavior are 
normal aspects of human sexuality. Both have been documented in many 
different cultures and historical eras. Despite the persistence of 
stereotypes that portray lesbian, gay and bisexual people as disturbed, 
several decades of research and clinical experience have led all mainstream 
medical and mental health organizations in this country to conclude that 
these orientations represent normal forms of human experience. Lesbian, gay 
and bisexual relationships are normal forms of human bonding. Therefore, 
these mainstream organizations long ago abandoned classifications of 
homosexuality as a mental disorder. "

You could have easily looked up all of this and more, instead of clinging 
to your own made-up idea that you already know has never been given any 
validity by any of the studies done by any major research agency.

But again, you are free to think whatever you want to think about gays. You 
can be as prejudiced as you want. And you can justify that based on 
religious beliefs, or on odd 'theories' that you invent to prop up your 
views, or you don't even have to justify your prejudice.  It's a free 
country and you can think whatever you want about gays. But make no mistake 
- while you can be prejudiced, THE LAW CANNOT. You have no justification 
for your prejudiced views being given any force in our laws.

comments.text:
+Azad Ward  All of that is more 'slippery slope' rhetoric in which you 
simply try to argue against some separate topic instead of THIS topic. You 
have still never offered a single word of argument to show that laws which 
denied civil marriage to same sex couples could possibly comply with the 
Constitution.  

HERE is how it REALLY works:

This country is a Constitutional Republic that values the rights of 
citizens, and requires laws to provide Equal Protection and requires Due 
Process of the law. It requires that all laws must serve a legally valid 
purpose and not simply disadvantage an unpopular group and amount to 
discrimination for its own sake. It requires that the actual EFFECT of the 
law must at the very least be rationally related to the stated GOAL for the 
law, and that stated goal must be a legitimate 'states interest'. 

And laws that deny civil marriage to same sex couples fail all of these 
basic tests for constitutional compliance, and that is why they are all 
being ruled unconstitutional all over the country.

They apply unequal legal treatment by disadvantaging the targeted group of 
same sex couples who wish to marry and receive the same important 
protections of law from civil marriage that are afforded to other couples 
who are allowed to legally marry. This causes real, particularized harm 
that is a matter of verified evidence in the judicial record. Even the 
opposing lawyers don't deny that these laws have this effect on the 
targeted group.

And in case after case, the lawyers tasked with defending these bans by 
offering some rational justification for the ban and some legitimate goal 
achieved by the ban were unable to do so. The justifications that have been 
offered are either false claims, fail to show a rational relationship 
between the effect of the law and the claimed goal for the law, or the 
claimed goal for the law wasn't even a legitimate states interest in the 
first place. None of the arguments offered to try to justify these laws has 
survived logical scrutiny.

We do not make harmful and unjust laws just to appease the personal 
prejudices of a group of citizens. That is not a valid purpose for a law. 
It does not matter what you personally think about gay citizens. Appeasing 
your personal prejudice is not a legitimate 'states interest'. The question 
is determined by looking at the LAW and whether it complies with the 
principles of the Constitution, not by looking at your personal views about 
those harmed by the law.

It would partially depend on WHY someone thinks that. It may be based in 
misinformation, religious beliefs, or it may be just plain prejudice.

But a question - how can you say that you have no problem with gays, and 
you are not saying they shouldn't have rights, but you object to them 
raising their kids?

Picture this - a woman marries a guy and has a kid, then they divorce and 
she is raising the kid alone. Then she gets honest with herself about the 
fact that she has always really been attracted to women. She meets her 
perfect soul mate (another woman) and they want to spend the rest of their 
lives together supporting each other as a couple and a family, no different 
from any other couple who fall in love and want to marry and spend their 
lives together. 

So in that scenario, if you don't think she should be raising her own child 
simply because she is a lesbian who has found a great relationship with 
another person, what do YOU think should happen? Should she never be 
allowed to be in a relationship and be forced by law to raise her kid 
alone? Should she be forced by law to choose between raising her kid and 
marrying her partner? How could a law interfere with someone's parenting 
and family life like that without violating that person's rights and 
violating the Constitution?

Answer: It can't. There's no legitimate reason for a law to interfere with 
someone raising their kid (either biological, stepchild, or adopted) simply 
because that person happens to be gay. Such laws would be unnecessary, 
harmful, discriminatory, and would serve no legitimate legal purpose. They 
would do nothing except appease the personal views of people who have an 
anti-gay prejudice, and that's not a valid reason to enact a law that would 
intrude on a citizen's rights like that.

BREAKING NEWS in the state if KANSAS - A few weeks ago, the 10th Circuit 
Federal Court of Appeals ruled that bans on civil marriage for same sex 
couples were unconstitutional, in a case that originated in the state 
of Utah. This 10th Circuit ruling applies to all other states within the 
10th circuit, including Kansas. Since then, the state of Kansas has been 
seeking to avoid or delay complying with this federal court decision by 
filing frivolous additional requests to the courts, even though this is now 
settled law in that circuit, and the state has requested the U.S. Supreme 
Court to grant a "stay" in the earlier ruling which would continue to delay 
implementation of the Circuit Court's mandate until all of these pointless 
and redundant cases are each dismissed. But today, the U.S. Supreme Court 
declined to issue such a "stay", meaning that same sex couples can now 
begin legally marrying in the state of Kansas, regardless of any additional 
foot-dragging and frivolous litigation attempted by the state to delay the 
implementation of the mandate from the 10th Circuit.   ﻿
comments.author: TheDavep2

comments.text:
BREAKING NEWS - a federal judge in SOUTH CAROLINA has just ruled that the 
state's ban on civil marriage for same sex couples is UNCONSTITUTIONAL. 
South Carolina is one of the states in the Fourth Federal Appeals Circuit, 
and the Fourth Circuit had recently ruled such bans unconstitutional in a 
case which originated in Virginia, which is also in the Fourth Circuit. 
These Federal Circuit court rulings affect ALL states within that circuit, 
meaning it directs South Carolina to stop enforcing their marriage ban 
along with the other states in the Fourth Circuit. But South Carolina has 
been seeking a way to disregard that federal ruling and continue banning 
same sex marriage in their state. This new ruling confirms that they are 
required to comply with the first federal appeals ruling and confirms that 
they must cease infringing on the rights of same sex couples who wish to 
legally marry. ﻿
